questions.text: A teacher presents with the following condition and hoarseness of the voice. Identify.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal nodule

 

Based on the description of the condition causing hoarseness in a teacher, a profession associated with voice strain, the most likely diagnosis is Vocal nodule.

 

Vocal nodules are bilateral, benign growths that typically occur at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords. They are often a result of vocal strain or overuse and present with a hoarse voice. The nodules are usually symmetrical and look like small bumps on either side of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal carcinoma usually presents as an irregular, often unilateral growth on the vocal cord, and it can cause hoarseness. The lesion may have an irregular surface and can vary in coloration from the surrounding tissue. It is typically associated with risk factors like smoking and alcohol use.

 

Option C. Reinke’s edema is characterized by the swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation in Reinke's space (the layer of the vocal cord). The cords appear swollen and may take on a polypoid appearance, often associated with a lower-pitched, hoarse voice. Smoking is a common risk factor.

 

Option D. Vocal polyps are usually unilateral and can vary in size. They are often the result of acute vocal trauma or misuse. Polyps can cause hoarseness and have a soft, fluid-filled appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are benign, symmetrical lesions typically located at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords, often resulting from chronic vocal strain, and present with symptoms of hoarseness.

questions.text: Which is the best stain for biopsy during laryngoscopy for vocal cord examination? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravital

 

The best stain for biopsy during laryngoscopy for vocal cord examination is Toluidine blue, which is a type of supravital stain.

 

Supravital staining allows for the observation of living cells and is particularly useful in this context because it can be used non-invasively during laryngoscopy. Toluidine blue has a high affinity for DNA and RNA, making it effective in highlighting areas with high cellular activity, such as cancerous growths. This stain is particularly useful for detecting early cancerous changes in the vocal cords, as it is absorbed more by cells with high nucleic acid content, indicating a proliferative or carcinomatous state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Silver nitrate: This is primarily used as a cauterizing agent and does not serve as a stain for examining vocal cord tissue in a biopsy. It is not suitable for detecting cellular abnormalities.

 

Option C. H&E (Hematoxylin and Eosin): While commonly used in pathology to stain tissue sections, H&E is not a supravital stain and requires invasive tissue preparation, which is not practical during laryngoscopy.

 

Option D. Congo red: This stain is used for detecting amyloid deposits and is not relevant to vocal cord examination for cancerous growths. It does not have the specificity required for identifying DNA and RNA activity in living cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue, a supravital stain, is the best stain for non-invasive detection of cancerous growths during laryngoscopy of the vocal cords due to its high uptake by cells with active DNA and RNA synthesis.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Montgomery T tube

 

Montgomery T tube is a type of silicone stent used in the management of tracheal and subglottic stenosis. It is T-shaped to allow it to fit snugly in the trachea with one limb exiting the stoma, allowing for breathing through the upper airway or the tube itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a device inserted between the trachea and the esophagus to facilitate speech in patients who have had a total laryngectomy

 

Option C. Blom-Singer prosthesis is a type of tracheoesophageal puncture voice prosthesis used for voice rehabilitation after a laryngectomy. When a patient has their larynx removed, typically due to cancer, they lose their natural voice. A Blom-Singer prosthesis is a one-way valve inserted between the trachea and the esophagus that allows air to be diverted into the esophagus to produce sound, enabling the patient to speak. It is placed during surgery or as an office procedure after the surgical site has healed.

 

Option D. A Grommet, also known as a tympanostomy tube or ventilation tube, is a small tube inserted into the eardrum to allow air to enter the middle ear. It is used to treat recurrent middle ear infections (acute otitis media) or to relieve chronic fluid accumulation in the middle ear (otitis media with effusion). Grommets help reduce the frequency of ear infections and improve hearing by allowing the continuous drainage of fluid and equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the external atmospheric pressure.

choices.text: It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx.
It is associated with an omega-shaped epiglottis.
Stridor is increased on crying and relieved on lying prone.
Surgical Tracheostomy is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Laryngomalacia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Surgical Tracheostomy is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:


Laryngomalacia is primarily managed conservatively, with observation being the mainstay of treatment. Tracheostomy is only required in select cases with severe respiratory obstruction, not as the first-line or treatment of choice. The condition typically resolves by 2 years of age as the laryngeal cartilages become more rigid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx: This is true. Laryngomalacia is indeed the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.

 

Option B. It is associated with an omega-shaped epiglottis: This is true. Direct laryngoscopy findings include elongated epiglottis curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

 

Option C. Stridor is increased on crying and relieved on lying prone: This is true. Stridor increases on crying but subsides when the child is placed in prone position. This clinical feature is characteristic of laryngomalacia and helps in its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly characterized by flaccid supraglottic structures causing inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying and improves in prone position; it typically resolves spontaneously by age 2 with conservative management being the mainstay of treatment, while tracheostomy is reserved only for severe cases.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown on x-ray. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double ring sign

 

The x-ray shows a round object in the esophagus, which is identified as a button battery due to the characteristic appearance known as the "double ring sign." This sign is seen when a button battery is lodged in the esophagus; the object appears to have two distinct concentric rings. The esophagus, which runs vertically in the body, causes the face of the battery or coin to present anteroposteriorly on the x-ray, which means it shows as a full circle when viewed from the front. A coin, unlike a button battery, does not have this double ring appearance. Recognizing the double ring sign is crucial because a button battery lodged in the esophagus is a medical emergency due to the risk of severe tissue damage from the battery's contents.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. String sign: This sign is typically associated with Crohn's disease and represents a narrowing of the bowel lumen, not applicable to foreign bodies in the esophagus.

 

Option C. Steeple sign: This sign is indicative of croup and appears as a tapering of the upper trachea on an x-ray, resembling a church steeple. It does not apply to the appearance of a button battery or coin in the esophagus.

Option D. Thumb sign: This sign is seen in epiglottitis, where the swollen epiglottis resembles a thumb on a lateral neck x-ray. It is unrelated to the presentation of a button battery in the esophagus.

Educational Objective:

 

The double ring sign on an x-ray indicates the presence of a button battery in the esophagus, distinguished by two concentric rings, which is critical to identify promptly due to the potential for severe complications.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents in ENT OPD with complaints of hearing trouble from the left side of the ear for the last 2 months. The doctor performs pure tone audiometry shown below. Interpret the audiogram? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left sided conductive deafness

 

Explanation:

 

The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows results for the left ear, indicated by the blue color. The audiogram demonstrates a significant air-bone gap, which is characteristic of conductive hearing loss. In conductive hearing loss, the air conduction thresholds are worse (higher dB levels) than the bone conduction thresholds, but the bone conduction remains within normal limits. This wide air-bone gap confirms the diagnosis of left-sided conductive deafness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness: Sensorineural hearing loss would present with both air and bone conduction thresholds being equally impaired, without a significant air-bone gap. This is not the case here.

 

Option C. Right sided conductive deafness: The audiogram is for the left ear (indicated by blue color), not the right ear. Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness: Similarly, this option is incorrect as the audiogram provided is for the left ear, and it shows conductive, not sensorineural, hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conductive hearing loss is indicated by a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry, with air conduction thresholds being worse than bone conduction thresholds, as seen in this left-sided case

questions.text: On Head impulse test, for a Left vestibular neuritis patient, Saccade will be in which direction? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right on left head rotation

 

In patients with left vestibular neuritis, the vestibular function on the left side is hypoactive, meaning it functions below normal levels. The head impulse test evaluates the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which helps maintain stable vision during head movements. When the head is moved to the left, the left vestibular system (which is hypoactive in this condition) should excite and the right side should inhibit. However, due to the hypoactivity on the left side, the expected response is delayed or diminished, causing the eyes to initially drift towards the hypoactive side (left) followed by corrective saccadic movements to the right. Therefore, saccades will be observed to the right during left head rotation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left on left head rotation: This is incorrect because in a left vestibular neuritis patient, the left vestibular system is hypoactive. Corrective saccades occur towards the opposite direction (right) when the hypoactive side (left) is stimulated.

 

Option B. Left on right head rotation: Incorrect because during right head rotation, the right vestibular system (which is unaffected) will function normally, leading to appropriate eye movement towards the right without corrective saccades.

 

Option D. Right on right head rotation: Incorrect because the right vestibular system is unaffected. Hence, the eyes will move correctly without saccades during right head rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In left vestibular neuritis, head impulse tests reveal saccades towards the right when the head is rotated to the left due to the hypoactive left vestibular system.

questions.text: A 3-year-old was brought to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing since 2 hours. A radiograph was done as shown below. What will be the next step to manage the patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Esophagoscopy

 

A round metallic foreign body lies in the midline just above the aortic knob, suggestive of a foreign body within the esophagus, the coin exceeds the diameter of the trachea. Also, both lung fields appear clear.  

 

A PA and lateral view X-ray of chest and abdomen should be done.

 

Treatment – Removal of foreign body by esophagoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchoscopy: Used if there is suspicion that the foreign body might have entered the respiratory tract. In this scenario, the foreign body is in the esophagus, not the trachea.

 

Option B. Tracheostomy: Not appropriate in this case as there is no indication of airway compromise that cannot be managed by less invasive means.

 

Option D. Heimlich’s Maneuver: This is used for choking due to an airway obstruction, not for foreign bodies lodged in the esophagus. It's inappropriate and could potentially cause harm by forcing the object into a more problematic position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected esophageal foreign bodies in children, esophagoscopy is the preferred method for both confirmation and removal of the object. It ensures that the foreign body is safely and effectively retrieved while minimizing risk to the patient.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the photograph:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal Hopkin's endoscope

 

Explanation: 

 

The instrument shown in the photograph is a Nasal Hopkin's endoscope. This endoscope is commonly used in ENT endoscopic procedures to provide a clear and magnified view of the nasal and sinus passages. It consists of a rigid rod lens system that allows visualization of the internal structures during diagnostic and surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frazier's straight suction tube: Frazier's straight suction tube is a different instrument used for suction during surgeries, particularly in nasal surgeries.

 

 

Option C. Atomizer: An atomizer is a device used to convert liquid medication into a fine mist for nasal application.

 

 

Option D. Tilley antral trochar and canula: The Tilley antral trochar and canula are used for procedures such as antral lavage or drainage of the maxillary sinus, particularly in Caldwell-Luc surgeries.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nasal Hopkin's endoscope is a critical tool in ENT endoscopic procedures, providing detailed visualization of nasal and sinus structures for both diagnostic and surgical purposes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serous Otitis media

 

Child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months with  air fluid levels on otoscopy is suggestive of serous otitis media.

 

Aetiology

 

  1. Eustachian tube block secondary to adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx
  2. Allergy
  3. Unresolved otitis media
  4. Viral infections – adeno and rhinovirus

 

Symptoms

 

The disease affects children of 5–8 years of age. The symptoms include:

 

  1. Conductive hearing loss.
  2. Delayed and defective speech. Because of hearing loss, development of speech is delayed or defective.
  3. Mild earaches.

 

Otoscopic Findings

 

  •  Tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex, and may appear yellow, grey or bluish in color.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of malleus or at the periphery of tympanic membrane
  • Tympanic membrane may show varying degree of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and tympanic membrane transparent
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted

 

Audiometry

 

  •  Pure tone audiometry shows conduction hearing loss
  •  Tympanometry will show B type curve

 

Treatment

 

1. Medical

 

  • Decongestants.
  • Antihistamines or sometimes steroids may be used in cases of allergy.
  • Antibiotics. They are useful in cases of upper respiratory tract infections or unresolved acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Middle Ear Aeration. Patients should repeatedly perform the Valsalva maneuver. Children can be given chewing gum to encourage repeated swallowing which opens the tube.

 

2. Surgical

 

  • Myringotomy and fluid aspiration
  • Grommet insertion
  • Tympanotomy and mastoidectomy
  • Surgical treatment of underlying causes like adenoid hypertrophy, tonsillar hypertrophy etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myringitis bullosa involves the formation of blisters on the tympanic membrane due to inflammation, often associated with viral infections like influenza.

 

  • Symptoms: It is characterized by severe pain, occasionally hearing loss, and a rapid onset following an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • The symptoms of prolonged hearing loss and the otoscopic findings of fluid levels visible in the image are not typical for myringitis bullosa, which usually presents with acute, painful blistering rather than effusion.

Option C. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, typically of rapid onset, involving signs of acute infection such as ear pain, fever, and general malaise.

 

  • Symptoms: The tympanic membrane often appears red and bulging due to the presence of pus and fluid, and the condition is usually accompanied by significant pain and fever.
  • Why Not: The child's symptoms described do not include acute infectious signs like significant pain or fever, and the duration of hearing loss suggests a more chronic condition.

Option D. Pneumo Tympanum refers to the presence of air in the middle ear space, which is not typically associated with fluid. It can occur due to trauma, barotrauma, or as a rare complication of severe nasal congestion.

 

  • Symptoms: This condition might present with a feeling of fullness or popping in the ear but not with the fluid level and air bubbles typically seen in fluid accumulation conditions.
  • Why Not: The presence of air bubbles alongside fluid specifically points towards fluid accumulation rather than just air, making pneumo tympanum less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serous otitis media requires comprehensive management to prevent long-term effects on hearing and speech development. Early intervention, both medical and surgical, is essential for restoring normal ear function and preventing recurrent episodes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 84

questions.text: What type of stridor occur in croup?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biphasic stridor

 

Given the question is about croup, the correct answer is Biphasic stridor, because croup usually affects the subglottic region and can cause narrowing that affects both phases of breathing.

 

Biphasic stridor is heard during both inhalation and exhalation and indicates a narrowing at the level of the vocal cords or just below them in the subglottic region. This type of stridor is characteristic of croup, which typically affects the subglottic area of the larynx.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound that occurs during inhalation. It is commonly associated with conditions that cause narrowing of the upper airway above the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Expiratory stridor is a wheezing sound heard during exhalation and is less common. It suggests a problem lower in the respiratory tract, such as the bronchioles or smaller bronchi.

 

Option D. No stridor would mean that there is no abnormal airway sound, which would not be applicable in the context of a discussion about croup, which typically presents with stridor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croup typically presents with biphasic stridor, which occurs during both inspiration and expiration, reflecting the subglottic airway narrowing characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes with excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge from the ear and HbA1c of 10. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Necrotizing otitis externa

 

Given the description of excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge, and the presence of uncontrolled diabetes (indicated by the high HbA1c level), the most likely diagnosis is Necrotizing otitis externa. This condition is a serious, potentially life-threatening infection that requires immediate medical attention.

 

Necrotizing otitis externa is a severe form of otitis externa that occurs primarily in diabetic patients or those who are immunocompromised. It is characterized by infection that extends into the bone and cartilage of the ear canal, causing severe pain, otorrhea (often bloody), and potentially serious complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa, commonly known as "swimmer's ear," is an inflammation of the ear canal that can cause ear pain and discharge. While it can be painful, it typically does not cause the severe symptoms seen in diabetic patients with poorly controlled blood sugar levels.

 

Option C. Serous otitis media involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It typically causes a feeling of fullness in the ear and decreased hearing but is not typically associated with severe pain or bloody discharge.

 

Option D. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, which can present with ear pain, fever, and hearing loss. In severe cases, it may lead to tympanic membrane rupture, which can cause bloody discharge. However, the pain is not usually described as excruciating and does not typically have the same level of severity as necrotizing otitis externa in a diabetic patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a diabetic patient presenting with excruciating ear pain and bloody otorrhea, the diagnosis of necrotizing otitis externa should be considered, especially when the patient has a significantly elevated HbA1c, indicating poor glycemic control.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles on the tympanic membrane and in the external auditory meatus, accompanied by features of facial nerve palsy. What is the diagnosis and which site is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ramsay hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

 

Clinical scenario is suggestive of Ramsay hunt syndrome (aka herpes zoster oticus).

 

Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay–Hunt Syndrome) - It is a viral infection (herpes zoster virus) involving geniculate ganglion of facial nerve. It is characterized by appearance of vesicles on the tympanic membrane, deep meatus, concha and retro auricular sulcus.

 

It appears as a rash of small tense blisters with surrounding erythema, preceded by pain in the ears for several days

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome and Basal Ganglion: Incorrect because Ramsay Hunt syndrome affects the geniculate ganglion, not the basal ganglion.

 

Option C. & D. Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by a triad of recurrent facial nerve paralysis, swelling of the lips (cheilitis granulomatosa), and a fissured tongue. It does not involve vesicular eruptions and primarily affects the facial appearance and function without vesicular rash. Paralysis may be recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a reactivation of herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a characteristic vesicular eruption on the ear and facial nerve palsy. Early recognition and treatment are vital to prevent complications and improve recovery.

questions.text: A patient with Reinke’s edema will have which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dysphonia

 

  • Dysphonia is the hallmark symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • The swelling in the vocal cords alters their vibration, leading to changes in voice quality, pitch, and loudness.
  • Patients often present with a deep, husky voice, and in severe cases, speech may become effortful.

 

Reinke’s Edema is polypoid degeneration of vocal cords. It is bilateral symmetrical swelling of the whole of membranous part of the vocal cords. This is due to oedema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords.

 

 

 

Etiology – Chronic irritation of vocal cords due to misuse of voice, heavy smoking, chronic sinusitis and laryngopharyngeal reflex.

 

Clinical features – Hoarseness, Dysphonia, patient uses false cords for voice production and this gives him a low-pitched and rough voice.

 

On indirect laryngoscopy, vocal cords appear as fusiform swellings with pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

 

Treatment - Decortication of the vocal cords, Voice rest and Speech therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dysphagia to Solids and Option C. Dysphagia to Liquids:

 

These symptoms relate to difficulty swallowing, which is not typically associated with Reinke’s edema unless there is significant involvement of adjacent structures affecting the swallowing mechanism, which is rare.

 

Option D. Diplophonia:

 

  • Diplophonia (the perception of two simultaneous pitches) can occur in conditions affecting vocal cord vibration but is not a classic feature of Reinke’s edema.
  • It may be observed in some cases of vocal cord lesions, such as polyps or cysts, but it is not a primary symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • Usually diplophonia is seen in unilateral vocal cord pathologies. The affected cord vibrates at a different frequency when compared with the normal cord which vibrates at its regular frequency. This is because vibrational characteristics of affected cord gets changed due to structural changes caused by the lesion. Hence 2 cords, vibrating at 2 different frequencies, will produce 2 different sounds. This is called as diplophonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke's edema primarily affects the vocal cords leading to characteristic symptoms related to voice changes where the patient may experience pain due to movement of swollen vocal cords. Heavy vocal cords require more effort by the vocal muscles to move them. Hence this extra effort of muscles causes pain and early vocal fatigue to the patient. Management involves addressing the underlying causes, surgical intervention, and supportive therapies like voice rest and speech therapy.

questions.text: The space between bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process is called: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hiatus Semilunaris

 

Explanation: 

 

The hiatus semilunaris is the gap between the bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process. It represents a two-dimensional space with a width of approximately 1-2mm. The uncinate process is a hook-like structure that runs from anterosuperior to posteroinferior direction, with its sharp posterosuperior border running parallel to the anterior border of the bulla ethmoidalis, creating this distinctive gap.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agger nasi :This is an elevation located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. When pneumatized, it contains agger nasi cells which may communicate with the frontal recess, but it is not the space between the bulla and uncinate process.

 

Option B. Olfactory cleft: This refers to the superior part of the nasal cavity where the olfactory epithelium is located, between the upper part of the septum and superior turbinate. It has no relation to the bulla ethmoidalis or uncinate process.

 

Option C. Frontonasal duct: This is an incorrect term that was historically used to describe the drainage pathway from the frontal sinus. No true duct exists; rather, the frontal sinus drains through the frontal recess into the middle meatus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The hiatus semilunaris is a critical landmark in the ostiomeatal complex, serving as an important reference point during endoscopic sinus surgery and forming part of the pathway for drainage of the anterior group of paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and bleeding. After diagnosis, it is determined to be inverted papilloma. What is the correct description of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benign and locally invasive

 

Inverted papilloma, also known as Schneiderian papilloma or Transitional cell papilloma, is characterized by its benign nature but with a propensity for local invasiveness. This type of tumor arises from the epithelial lining of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses and is notable for its tendency to grow inward into the underlying stroma rather than outward.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D. Malignant/Malignant and locally invasive: These are incorrect as inverted papilloma is primarily benign, though it requires aggressive management due to its invasive nature.

 

Option C. Benign and non-invasive: This is incorrect because, although benign, inverted papillomas are distinctly characterized by their local invasiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally invasive tumor primarily affecting the nasal cavity, requiring aggressive surgical management due to its invasive characteristics and potential complications. Regular follow-up is crucial due to the risk of recurrence and rare malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child post-tonsillectomy comes to you with complaints of snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing and a slight decrease in hearing. On examination, you notice a high arched palate. His school performance is deteriorating as well. His mother is worried. What is the next line of management for this child?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

The child's symptoms suggest the presence of adenoid hypertrophy, which is contributing to eustachian tube dysfunction, leading to serous otitis media. This condition can result in conductive hearing loss, which may be contributing to his school performance issues. Additionally, the presence of snoring and mouth breathing indicates that the adenoids may be sufficiently enlarged to obstruct the airway, particularly during sleep.

 

Next Steps in Management: Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This surgical intervention is recommended to address both the adenoid hypertrophy and the associated middle ear effusion. Removing the adenoids can help open up the airway and improve nasal breathing, while grommet insertion (myringotomy with tube placement) helps ventilate the middle ear and prevent fluid accumulation, improving hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy Alone: While this would address the nasal obstruction, it might not adequately resolve the middle ear effusion without the addition of grommets.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a repair procedure for a perforated eardrum, not relevant to this case as the main issue is middle ear effusion, not tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Conservative Management: Given the impact on the child’s hearing and school performance, plus the physical symptoms, conservative management would likely be insufficient in providing relief.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In the presence of tracheal deviation as indicated on a chest X-ray, which procedure is the most difficult to perform? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

A tracheostomy involves creating an opening through the neck into the trachea, which may become complicated when the trachea is deviated. In cases of tracheal deviation, the trachea is not in its usual midline position, which can make locating the correct spot for incision more challenging. This difficulty is increased because the trachea's position may not be easily palpable or visible due to its displacement, which can complicate the procedure and increase the risk of complications.

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal airway: A laryngeal airway (LMA) is inserted above the larynx at the supraglottic level. Since this procedure does not involve the trachea directly, a deviated trachea does not affect the placement of an LMA, making it relatively easy to perform.

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: While endotracheal intubation may become slightly more difficult with tracheal deviation, it usually remains manageable. The main challenge might be encountering some resistance or needing to adjust the angle of the tube. However, with careful maneuvering, the endotracheal tube can still be guided into the trachea.

Option D. Cricothyroidotomy: This procedure involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane, located above the trachea at the level of the larynx. Because the tracheal deviation occurs below this point, it does not directly impact the cricothyroidotomy, making it a viable option even with tracheal deviation.

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy can be more challenging in cases of tracheal deviation due to the altered position of the trachea, making the precise location for incision difficult to identify.

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule which are re-opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced.

 

In Modified Young's operation, partial closure of the nostril is done to avoid discomfort.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasomotor rhinitis - Typically managed with medications such as antihistamines and nasal sprays; surgery is not a standard treatment.

 

Option C. Invasive aspergillosis - Treatment involves antifungal medications; surgical debridement may be necessary but does not involve closing the nostrils.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis - Managed with allergy medications, immunotherapy, and avoiding allergens; surgery is not indicated for occluding nostrils.

 

Educational Objective:


Young's operation is a unique surgical technique reserved for severe cases of atrophic rhinitis where other treatments have failed. This procedure helps in restoring the normal function and structure of the nasal mucosa by temporarily occluding the nostrils to allow healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 173

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the ENT OPD with complaints of abnormal noise during breathing, the severity of which increases during crying. On examination, inspiratory stridors are heard and on laryngoscopy, the following finding is seen. The diagnosis would be? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laryngomalacia

 

Explanation: 

 

The baby presents with abnormal noise during breathing that worsens with crying, and inspiratory stridor, indicating an upper airway issue. The laryngoscopy image shows an omega-shaped epiglottis, which is characteristic of laryngomalacia. Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants and results from the collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital laryngeal web: A congenital laryngeal web would present with a hoarse cry and respiratory distress due to the fusion of the vocal cords. The airway would be significantly compromised, as shown below.

 

 

Option C. Congenital subglottic stenosis: Subglottic stenosis would show a narrowed subglottic area below the vocal cords, which is not consistent with the omega-shaped epiglottis seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Congenital bilateral choanal atresia: Choanal atresia involves the blockage of the nasal passages and presents with difficulty breathing, particularly while feeding, but does not typically present with the findings of an omega-shaped epiglottis or inspiratory stridor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying and is identified by the presence of an omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is exhibiting symptoms of a low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough that have persisted for the last 5 days. Upon examination, he displays a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly elevated respiratory rate. The chest X-ray reveals subglottic narrowing, resembling a steeple shape. Among the listed treatment options, which one is NOT recommended for managing this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parenteral cefotaxime

 

The presence of the steeple sign on the x-ray indicates a diagnosis of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).

 

However, it is important to note that parenteral cefotaxime (antibiotic) is not recommended for its treatment as the causative organisms are most commonly viral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Recommended in severe cases of croup for its ability to reduce swelling in the airway and improve symptoms quickly.

 

Option C. Helium Oxygen Mixture (Heliox): Used to ease the work of breathing in severe cases of croup by reducing airway resistance.

 

Option D. Intramuscular Dexamethasone: A corticosteroid that reduces airway inflammation and is a standard treatment for croup to alleviate symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Most common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The image provided is an endoscopic view of the nasopharynx. The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, which is located posterior to the torus tubarius. The torus tubarius is an elevation formed by the cartilaginous portion of the Eustachian tube, and the fossa of Rosenmüller is the recess behind this elevation. Site number 2 in the image corresponds to the fossa of Rosenmüller, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: This represents the posterior pharyngeal wall, which is not the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option C. 3: This represents another area of the nasopharynx but is not the typical site for the origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option D. 4: This represents the opening of the Eustachian tube. While nasopharyngeal carcinoma can affect this area, it is not the most common primary site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes infection involving the geniculate ganglion? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes zoster infection (varicella-zoster virus) involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It presents as a triad of facial nerve palsy, vesicular eruptions on the pinna and external auditory canal, and vestibulocochlear symptoms. The infection represents a reactivation of the herpes zoster virus that had remained dormant in the geniculate ganglion after previous chickenpox infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome: This is a rare manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, and facial nerve palsy. It is not related to herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion. The facial palsy in this condition is due to granulomatous infiltration of the facial nerve.

 

Option C. Bell's Palsy: While this is also a facial nerve paralysis, Bell's palsy is idiopathic in nature. Although some theories suggest that herpes simplex virus may be involved in some cases of Bell's palsy, it does not specifically involve vesicular eruptions or definitive evidence of geniculate ganglion involvement as seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome: This syndrome (also called Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome) is characterized by recurrent or persistent facial swelling, recurrent facial paralysis, and a fissured tongue (lingua plicata). It is not caused by herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion but is thought to be related to granulomatous disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is specifically characterized by facial nerve palsy due to herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion, presenting with the distinctive triad of facial paralysis, ear/mouth vesicles, and auditory/vestibular symptoms.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided as he will have aspirin intolerance.

 

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

 

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

 

Aspirin and COX – 1 inhibitors can exacerbate asthma hence they should be avoided. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

 

The provocative challenge test with aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is the only diagnostic method.

 

Aspirin desensitization is an important therapeutic option in patients with ST, especially in those patients suffering from recurrent NPs, anosmia, and overdependence on systemic corticosteroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole and Option B. Co-amoxiclav: These are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections, including sinusitis, and do not affect COX-1 activity.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: An antibiotic that is generally used for serious infections where other antibiotics are not suitable. It does not interact with the COX-1 pathway.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

choices.text: Identify the source of bleeding
Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding in the external auditory canal following trauma. The next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

 

Given the situation of trauma and the presence of blood in the external auditory canal, the most appropriate next step is to keep the ear dry to avoid any additional complications and to provide oral medications for pain, possible infection, and to reduce inflammation.

 

Keeping the ear dry and giving oral medications is a standard approach for managing a bloody discharge from the ear following trauma. This usually includes avoiding water in the ear to prevent infection and prescribing oral antibiotics if there is a suspicion of bacterial infection. Pain relief medication may also be provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirating the clot is generally not the first step in management unless there's a need for immediate assessment of the underlying structures, and if there's concern for ongoing bleeding that may be occluding the canal and impeding examination.

 

Option B. Identifying the source of bleeding is important, especially if the bleeding is significant or ongoing. However, this would typically follow initial conservative management unless the bleeding is profuse.

 

Option D. Syringing (ear irrigation) is contraindicated in the presence of a bloody discharge following trauma, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and increase the risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After trauma to the external auditory canal with bloody discharge, it is important to keep the ear dry and initiate treatment with oral medications, such as analgesics and possibly antibiotics, to manage pain, prevent infection, and reduce inflammation.
